data.text:
A spectacular publication from the estate of Niklas Luhmann

»Politics is not a pleasure; it has little to do with how we can build up reserves, warm up, educate ourselves, or find a woman.«

The best introduction to Luhmann’s political sociology yet

Luhmann developed his theory of politics when he was standing in for Theodor W. Adorno in Frankfurt in the 1960s. The book at hand is the first one to offer a comprehensive account of Niklas Luhmann’s political sociology.

Unimpressed by the trends of contemporary ideology critique, in the 1960s Luhmann developed a political theory whose basic principles he then adhered to and which remained largely unchanged. Political Sociology presents articles that have previously been unknown and in terms of methodology were not then overtaken by later publications. The role of the public in administration and politics, and the political systems in socialist countries are two of the subjects the author addresses. Adopting the style of an oral presentation, Luhmann argues from a far more sociological point of view than he does in his later works, making ideas from other academic disciplines recede into the background.
